column5: Chicken manure is a temporary solution for plants.
column6: It has a lot of urea.
column7: Apart from the urea, there is another downside to chicken manure.
column8: Chicken manure usually comes with mites from the chicken.
column9: The mites will immediately find comfort in your passion fruit plants.
column10: You will realize that your plants are not growing well.
column11: They will not even grow at all.
column12: The mites will now thrive because they have food.
column13: You have moved them from a temporary home to a new place where they can grow and multiply.
column14: That’s why I discourage using chicken manure unless it is sanitized.
column15: There are companies that sanitize and process chicken manure.
column16: That processed chicken manure is good.
column17: I understand there are companies selling sanitized chicken manure.
column18: They process it and supply it to animal feed factories.
column19: The factories make animal feed using it.
column20: That’s why I think sanitized chicken manure is better.
column21: In the market, it is good to find sanitized chicken manure.
column22: It is better for your farm.
column24: Now we have the other manure.
column25: Yes, we have added our fertilizer.
column26: It is also deep, two feet.
column27: Yes, it becomes like a skill, right?
column29: This is so that you can accommodate a good amount of manure.
column30: Once you return the soil, the roots will now be at ease to develop.
column31: The soil there is not as compact as before.
column32: Sure, so there you will have some good work.
column34: We now come to planting the plants.
column35: For passion fruit, you should put it at the center of the hole.
column36: Not sideways, but at the center.
column37: Place it at the center of the hole so that you don’t alter the dimensions.
column38: The measurements of the hole are important.
column39: Someone may have measured two meters by two meters.
column40: But once you have planted, you realize it’s one meter on one side and two meters on the other.
column41: You realize that you have an interval between the plants.
column42: Now you have planted the plants.
column44: It has rained, lucky for you.
column45: For us here, we have used button drippers.
column46: We have installed a good system so that we have water 24/7.
column48: We just touch the soil and feel the moisture content using our hands.
column49: Once you have watered, you’re good to go.
column50: The next step is trellising and general management.
column52: You can see we have used some ropes.
column53: On these ropes, you don’t tie directly to the plants.
column54: We use a thing that we put to the ground.
column55: Then we start aligning the plant to the rope.
column56: This is the wire now that connects to the rope, which supports the plants.
column57: The reason for this is because we realize that when we use these ropes to tie, it gets to a point that...
column58: The plants are now starting to shrink at that place.
column59: It’s like you are choking the plant by its neck.
column60: You are also blocking the movement of nutrients.
column61: When the plant starts thickening, you realize it is being restricted at that point.
column63: That is one of the reasons we decided to change.
column64: Usually, we prefer you use synthetic materials, or you can use organic ones.
column65: Organic options like coconut chips are nice.
column66: Coconut chips are very organic and effective.
column67: Once the plant has grown to a certain level, like this one, and we cut it, the coconut chips will drop down and decompose.
column68: But for the plastic synthetic ones, they are harder to reuse.
column69: After they have served their purpose, you cannot easily reuse them.
column70: This is due to the condition they have been exposed to.
column71: We also ensure they do not harm the plants.
column72: Now, the other part is pruning.
column73: Pruning is a very critical stage.
column74: This is because you are introducing a cut to the plant.
column75: That cut becomes an opening for vectors and diseases to enter.
column76: When pruning, we encourage people to remove any other shoots that grow from the plant.
column77: This is done until the plant has reached the wire.
column78: From the ground to the wire, the plant should have a single main stem.
column79: Here, we have used two main stems.
column80: You can see two stems, but there are no branches growing out of them below the wire.
column81: Some people prefer to use one main stem.
column82: When it reaches the wire, they allow it to divide into two or more branches at that point.
column84: The double stems can be attacked by a disease on one side.
column85: If this happens, you can cut from the main stem.
column86: Since it’s the main stem, you can get another piece from there.
column87: This way, you don’t need to buy a whole new plant to replace it.
column88: So, you are encouraging the double stem method.
column89: The double stem style is good for passion fruit production.
column90: Now, you must discourage any new shoots from the main stem.
column91: Once it has reached the wire, you can start encouraging the shoots to come out.
column92: There is one thing I forgot to mention.
column93: Every passion fruit plant produces three things:
column94: A tender shoot, a flower, and a fruit.
column95: If it’s not a flower, it will produce a shoot.
column96: However, the flower and the fruit usually come at the same time.
column97: You can see here we have a shoot, and here we have a flower.
column98: You will keep on discouraging the new shoots.
column99: Once you have left the main shoots, they are called laterals.
column101: If you count from the base up to 1.5 meters,
column102: You should have anywhere between 25 to 30 laterals.
